Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Delete private packages and packages with 0 downloads" (#8314) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
I can't delete a package which is private and I don't need it anymore. I used it for testing before and now I can't delete it.

### Describe the solution you'd like
You should be able to delete private packages and packages with 0 downloads. If package is private or has 0 downloads, there will be no project which depends on it, so it would be safe to delete it.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Can nuget restore download packages from private repository using only API Key?" (#10241) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
Can `nuget restore` (`dotnet restore`, `msbuild -t:Restore <path to project>`) use API key for the private repository to get packages from it, or Username / Password are required?

Every Nuget documentation page that mentioned API keys is for uploading the package to Nuget repository (which works fine for me), and none of them tells you if you can use API key when restoring packages. The [discussion](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6233) raises the similar issue, but I could find there a definite answer to this question.
Answer [here](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/3664#issuecomment-354946142) also hints that username/password are required.

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version: 5.7.0.6726

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 3.1.403

VS version (if appropriate): 16.7.7

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): 10.0.17134 Build 17134

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: N/A

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Have a package in a private repo that requires you to provide login/password in order to download a package. (Let's call it RepoP)

2. Have a project and references the package mentioned above.

3. Have valid API key that allows you to upload package to the _RepoP_

4. Set `nuget.config`

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
    <configuration>
      <config />
      <packageRestore>
        <!-- Allow NuGet to download missing packages -->
        <add key="enabled" value="True" />
    
        <!-- Automatically check for missing packages during build in Visual Studio -->
        <add key="automatic" value="True" />
      </packageRestore>
      <packageSources>
        <clear />
        <add key="nuget" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
        <add key="RepoP" value="<RepoP Url>" />
      </packageSources>
      <apikeys>
        <add key="<RepoP Url>" value="<Valid Encrypted API Key>" />
      </apikeys>
    </configuration>

5. Use `nuget restore <project path> -ConfigFile .\nuget.config`

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)
Cannot provide that, but nuget requests user to enter login/password for the RepoP repository.

### Sample Project

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet pack does not include Compile Pack="true" when multi-targeting" (#10239) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: dotnet.exe
NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 5.8.0.6860
dotnet.exe --version: 5.0.100-rc.2.20479.15
OS version: Windows 10
Worked before? Not that I can tell, I tried 1.1.14, 2.1.811, 3.1.302, 3.1.403, 5.0.100-rc.2.20479.15

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. `dotnet new classlib`
1. Attempt to pack one of the source files (`<Compile>`) as a content file
1. Make the project mutli-target with `<TargetFrameworks>`
1. Run `dotnet pack`
1. Inspect the output .nupkg and see if there are `contentFiles`

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>netstandard1.0;netstandard1.1</TargetFrameworks>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <Compile Update="Class1.cs" Pack="true" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

**Problem:** does not include the content files at all.

```
_rels/.rels
PackContent.nuspec
lib/netstandard1.0/PackContent.dll
lib/netstandard1.1/PackContent.dll
[Content_Types].xml
package/services/metadata/core-properties/a856c12125244f57bf30839499a16703.psmdcp
```

## Other suggested things

The following workarounds work:

### Don't multi-target

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>netstandard1.0</TargetFramework>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <Compile Update="Class1.cs" Pack="true" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

**Problem:** does not multi-target which may be a requirement.

```
_rels/.rels
PackContent.nuspec
lib/netstandard1.0/PackContent.dll
content/Class1.cs
contentFiles/cs/netstandard1.0/Class1.cs
[Content_Types].xml
package/services/metadata/core-properties/4739f3f575954af387728acd57ff525a.psmdcp
```

### Add and remove the item

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>netstandard1.0;netstandard1.1</TargetFrameworks>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <Compile Remove="Class1.cs" />
    <Compile Include="Class1.cs" Pack="true" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

**Problem:** works perfectly, but a bit painful to both remove and add the item.

```
_rels/.rels
PackContent.nuspec
lib/netstandard1.0/PackContent.dll
lib/netstandard1.1/PackContent.dll
content/Class1.cs
contentFiles/cs/netstandard1.0/Class1.cs
contentFiles/cs/netstandard1.1/Class1.cs
[Content_Types].xml
package/services/metadata/core-properties/6312600f2bc343e882db96fd6bc3b99f.psmdcp
```

### Pack as content

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>netstandard1.0;netstandard1.1</TargetFrameworks>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <Content Include="Class1.cs" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

**Problem:** does not pack under a C# (`cs`) folder:

```
_rels/.rels
PackContent.nuspec
lib/netstandard1.0/PackContent.dll
lib/netstandard1.1/PackContent.dll
content/Class1.cs
contentFiles/any/netstandard1.0/Class1.cs
contentFiles/any/netstandard1.1/Class1.cs
[Content_Types].xml
package/services/metadata/core-properties/c812a30ee9a64a3c807dce065ce96403.psmdcp
```

### Sample Project

[PackContent.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/5505348/PackContent.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NominateProjectAsync should only restore the project being passed" (#7622) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet version: latest
VS version: dev16 (and probably dev15 too)
OS version: win10

CPS-based projects will trigger a `NominateProjectAsync` when the active configuration changes (or when the project template is unfolded too). 

Repro steps:
1- With nuget package restore settings enabled, create an empty solution 
2- Add New Project -> Class Library (.Net Standard)
3- Add New Project -> Console App (.Net Framework)
4- Change the current active configuration from Debug to Release.

At this stage the CPS-based library will trigger a `NominateProjectAsync` doing [1], [2] and [3] and the expected `restoreinformation` should only contain the `.Net Standard` project but it also contains the another `csproj` library. Resuming:

Expected: `restoreinformation` should only contain the project being nominated
Actual: `restoreinformation` is also containing other projects in the solution which were not nominated

Additional scenarios where this issue also impacts:
- `runintellisensebuild` is also triggered as the result of the `csproj` (unnecessary) nomination and might cause perf impact
- When unfolding a multi-project template which contains at least one netstandard library in it (Xamarin Cross Platform App for instance) the solution perf load might be significantly impacted if any of the other projects being unfolded contain several nuget packages to be restored (Android project for instance in the Xamarin example mentioned above). 

Finally I could not find where the project unique name is being honored in the `VsSolutionRestoreService` [4] or [5]

[1] https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/blob/ddfc471669edc4b2806de3b2a731c7c10c58f2a3/src/Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.Managed.VS/ProjectSystem/VS/NuGet/PackageRestoreInitiator.PackageRestoreInitiatorInstance.cs#L77

[2] https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/blob/ddfc471669edc4b2806de3b2a731c7c10c58f2a3/src/Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.Managed.VS/ProjectSystem/VS/NuGet/PackageRestoreInitiator.PackageRestoreInitiatorInstance.cs#L103

[3] https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/blob/ddfc471669edc4b2806de3b2a731c7c10c58f2a3/src/Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.Managed.VS/ProjectSystem/VS/NuGet/PackageRestoreInitiator.PackageRestoreInitiatorInstance.cs#L148

[4] https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager/VsSolutionRestoreService.cs#L99-L109

[5] https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager/VsSolutionRestoreService.cs#L142-L144

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Multitarget restore (net471;netcoreapp2.0) fails due to netstandard1.3 transitive reference" (#7220) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Take the following project file and restore it (using `dotnet restore` , `msbuild /t:Restore` or `NuGet.exe restore`):

```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk" >
    <PropertyGroup>
        <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
        <TargetFrameworks>net471;netcoreapp2.0</TargetFrameworks>
    </PropertyGroup>

    <ItemGroup>
        <PackageReference Include="log4net" Version="2.0.8" />
    </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

The client reports attempt to downgrade multiple system packages, for example:

```
Detected package downgrade: System.Threading from 4.3.0 to 4.0.11. Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version.
MultitargetRestore -> log4net 2.0.8 -> System.Console 4.0.0 -> runtime.win.System.Console 4.3.0 -> System.Threading (>= 4.3.0)
MultitargetRestore -> log4net 2.0.8 -> System.Threading (>= 4.0.11)
```

All of the following needs to hold:

1. Multitarget .NET Framework (any) and .NET Core 2.0. Passes if targeted separately or with a different second framework (i.e. net45+net471 or netcoreapp1.1 and netcoreapp2.0).
2. Output type set to Exe. Passes for library output.
3. Reference log4net package (or possibly any package that has dependencies for netstandard1.x and not for netstandard2.0).

I have also encountered significantly harder to reproduce case when `netcoreapp1.1` and `netcoreapp2.0` was targeted, but I'm not able to reproduce on a simple project at this point.

Workaround is to explicitly reference all of those packages with a correct version.

[MultitargetRestore.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/2306246/MultitargetRestore.zip)

Ensure that restore has run and that you have included 'net46' in the TargetFrameworks for your project.

See commit [here](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/Connected%20Experience/_git/DevCore/commit/6331cca5dc765281a28a53de0fed576781b1e248?refName=refs%2Fheads%2Fv15.4)

...

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)

### Sample Project

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Msbuild pack doesn't choose the right version for ProjectReferences" (#6379) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

- NuGet product used: VS2017
- NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): Package Manager Console Host Version 4.5.0.4685
- VS version (if appropriate): 15.5.2
- OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): Version	10.0.16299 Build 16299
- Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: n/a

## Steps to Reproduce
There are two solutions files, ``NugetProjectRefTest_Core`` and ``NugetProjectRefTest_Net``, found respectively under the NugetProjectRefTest_Core and NugetProjectRefTest_Net folders.

- Build both solutions.

__Note__: the zip file contains all source, binaries and nuget packages, so no real need to rebuild the solutions.

### Back Ground
Each solution folder contains 2 DLLs and 1 console app.
The console app reference ``DLL1`` as a project reference and ``DLL1`` reference ``DLL2`` also as a project reference. All 4 DLLs have a nuget version number of ``8.0.0-Alpha001``.

## Expected Behavior
That both ``CoreDLL1`` nuget packages, which depends on their respective ``CoreDLL2`` package, reference the correct ``CoreDLL2`` package version number.

## Actual Behavior
- Open the ``.\NugetProjectRefTest\NugetProjectRefTest_Core\CoreDll1\bin\Debug\CoreDll1.8.0.0-Alpha001.nupkg``, the nuspec dependencies node looks like this:
```
       <dependencies>
            <group targetFramework=".NETCoreApp2.0">
                <dependency id="CoreDll2" version="8.0.0-Alpha001" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
            </group>
        </dependencies>
```
Notice that the ``CoreDLL2`` version is listed correctly as ``8.0.0-Alpha001``.

Now open the ``.\NugetProjectRefTest\NugetProjectRefTest_Net\Packages.Output\NetDll1.8.0.0-Alpha001-Debug.nupkg``, the nuspec dependencies node looks like this:
```
        <dependencies>
            <group targetFramework=".NETFramework4.7.1">
                <dependency id="NetDll2" version="1.0.0" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />
            </group>
        </dependencies>
```
Notice that the ``CoreDLL2`` version is *not* listed correct, its showing ``1.0.0`` but is should read:  ``8.0.0-Alpha001``.

### Sample Project
[NugetProjectRefTest.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1601174/NugetProjectRefTest.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Discrepancy in trailing backslashes in NuGetPackageFolders" (#6032) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello,

Using latest VS 15.4.0, Nuget package manager 4.4.0, I have started getting an error when trying to build a project referencing a Nuget package containing this .targets file:

```
<Project xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/developer/msbuild/2003">
  <ItemGroup>
    <None Include="$(NuGetPackageFolders)\SweekCms.Admin\1.0.24\content\sweek-admin.tar">
      <Link>sweek-admin.tar</Link>
      <CopyToOutputDirectory>PreserveNewest</CopyToOutputDirectory>
    </None>
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

Error is: 

```
1>C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Community\MSBuild\15.0\Bin\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(4406,5): error MSB3025: The source file "C:\Users\Bjorn\.nuget\packages\" is actually a directory.  The "Copy" task does not support copying directories.
1>C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Community\MSBuild\15.0\Bin\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(4406,5): error MSB3030: Could not copy the file "C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\NuGetFallbackFolder\SweekCms.Admin\1.0.10\content\sweek-admin.tar" because it was not found.
```

This worked in june. When looking at the obj\WebApplication1.csproj.nuget.g.props I see that the NuGetPackageFolders value is:

```
<NuGetPackageFolders Condition=" '$(NuGetPackageFolders)' == '' ">C:\Users\Bjorn\.nuget\packages\;C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\NuGetFallbackFolder</NuGetPackageFolders>
```

ie. a discrepancy in trailing backslashes. When changing the .targets file to utilize NuGetPackageFolderRoot, it started working again.

Looks a bit like this comment here: https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/1250#issuecomment-303791974

I fixed my issue, but giving a heads up in case something is wrong here?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Apply recommended changes to the solution restore worker design" (#4456) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Follow-up on NuGet/NuGet.Client#1154.

Address feedback comments from the aforementioned PR to the solution restore worker design:
- Cancellation token handling policy and contract
- Handling `JoinableTask` in restore operation
- Missing xml documentation and comments

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "When a project needs to be restored, consider making autorestore restore the minimal set of projects" (#4451) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Extend auto-restore + init.ps1 fix to all project types" (#4478) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I introduced a fix just for CPS-based (xplat) PackageReference projects to help init.ps1 work properly after auto-restore is complete. The fix only works when there is at least one xplat PackageReference project in the solution. We made this selective change to limit risk.

We should extend this to non-xplat PackageReference, and project.json-based solutions. Even packages.config projects? Not sure.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The Microsoft author signing certificate will be updated as soon as November 1st, 2020" (#47) at NuGet/Announcements
